Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Small: Location, location, location (L3): Support for Geo-Centric Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent years have seen the proliferation of a variety of sensors embedded in different environments, and the increasing availability of smart wearable devices. Together these trends have resulted in the growth of sensor data of interest to many communities across social, economic, health-care, and scientific domains. This has led to the emergence of geo-centric applications: a class of applications that can process and extract rich information from the sensor data to provide novel services to users. However, these applications currently suffer from poor performance and failures due to the limited computing and storage resources available on the devices and their location dependency. This project will develop new computing abstractions, algorithms, and systems, that enable a new frontier of geo-centric applications to be supported. The goal of this project is to catalyze the role of computer systems in meeting the needs of emerging geo-centric applications in mobile, sensor, and Internet-of-things (IoT) areas.

This project will build a system called Location, location, location: Support for Geo-Centric Applications - or L3 for short. A number of novel system and application abstractions to manage the dynamism that arises from location in support of geo-centric applications will be developed. First is the concept of a Resource cloud, a system-facing abstraction that is geo-aware and manages a set of changing resources based on publish-subscribe and matchmaking. Second is the concept of a Resource container, an application-facing abstraction that provides policy-based resource selection and allocation across a diverse set of resources including storage, computation, and even data sources, to meet the specific requirements of an application. The project will address specific research problems that arise in the design and implementation of the Resource cloud and Resource container, including: on-demand resource provision to the Resource cloud, collective matching of resource requests that scale to diverse resource types and to highly shared resources, and automated resource policy generation and optimization based on application requirements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The proliferation of geo-dispersed sensors and the increasing availability of smart wearable devices have led to an emerging class of user/data-centric applications dependent on geo-specific resources that we term geo-centric applications. A common thread across these geo-centric applications is the presence of dynamism at many levels including mobility of applications and resources, unpredictable production and consumption of data, uncertain sharing of resources "in the wild", and potential for failure due to non-local resource dependence.

This project has developed a number of novel algorithms, systems, and techniques to manage this dynamism arising from location in support of geo-centric applications. It has developed a geo-distributed storage system called Wiera that utilizes multi-tiered storage across multiple data centers to support storage-based containers for geo-centric applications. It has resulted in a framework for geo-distributed data analytics that considers both compute and network cost as a key metric. This project developed new fault tolerance techniques for geo-distributed streaming analytics, applied to both individual and multiple concurrent queries. It built a framework of edge resources to satisfy the computation and storage needs of nearby mobile devices, sensors and IoT devices.

This project has directly supported three graduate students, three undergraduate REU students (including one female student), and one undergraduate RA. It has led to publication of multiple papers, and release of open source-code shared with the community. This project has resulted in new scheduling, resource management, and data placement algorithms for distributed computing. This project will result in a computing infrastructure that will make it easier for mobile users and sensor-driven applications to access data and computation on-demand resulting in improved quality of life across social, healthcare, and economic domains.
